docs.lead_paragraph: Volunteer firefighters here are angry that Tioga County has been waging a legal battle for two years to avoid paying death benefits to the widow of a former Newark Valley fire chief who collapsed and died at a house fire. The issue is as much about emotions as it is about the law for people in this rural county 35 miles west of Binghamton along the Pennsylvania border, where volunteers outnumber paid firefighters by at least 10 to 1 and where community life still revolves around the firehouse.

headline.main: County's Battle to Avoid Paying Benefits in Fire Chief's Death Angers Volunteer Firefighters

docs.abstract: Volunteer firefighters throughout Tioga County, NY, express anger at county's two-year legal battle to avoid paying death benefits to widow of former Newark Valley fire chief Guy Pollard, who collapsed and died at house fire; county has twice appealed decisions by New York State Workmen's Compensation Board granting widow, Sharon Pollard, $6,980 in burial costs and $400 a week to replace her husband's lost income (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, officials from the National Football League Coaches Association, angry at what they thought was unfair treatment by the owners, met with Jeffrey Kessler, perhaps the most renowned sports antitrust lawyer in the country, in a hotel ballroom in Indianapolis. The topic of conversation? The N.F.L. assistant coaches were considering suing the league for antitrust violations. One of the assistant's biggest complaints has been that since the N.F.L. office keeps track of the salaries of almost every coach, and individual teams can find out approximately what those salaries are, there is almost a built-in salary ceiling. Some coaches wanted to sue to remove those restraints, members of the coaches association said last week. The N.F.L. says it in no way violates antitrust laws.

headline.main: Assistant Coaches Are Seeking Better Treatment From N.F.L. Owners

docs.abstract: National Football League assistant coaches are considering suing league for antitrust violations; one of biggest complaints has been that since NFL office keeps track of salaries of almost every coach, and individual teams can find out approximately what those salaries are, there is almost built-in salary ceiling; some coaches want to sue to remove those restraints; photo of Larry Kennan, director of NFL Coaches Association (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Insurance Plan of New Jersey, the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, has come under the supervision of state insurance regulators. The State Department of Banking and Insurance announced that it had issued an order of administrative supervision on Sept. 8, after the nonprofit company fell $9.5 million short of a required cash reserve of $15.4 million, the amount it would theoretically cost to pay claims for all its 195,000 New Jersey members, said Winnie Comfort, a spokeswoman for the department. Regulators also found a backlog of claim payments, unacceptable delays in getting doctors' appointments, and staff shortages in laboratories and record-keeping divisions, according to a department statement. KIRSTY SUCATO

headline.main: Cash Low, H.M.O. Goes Under State Supervision

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is often said that New Jersey's struggle for identity arises from its proximity to Philadelphia and New York City, which influences how its residents perceive themselves. But a major factor may also be its fragmented nature. There is no one New Jersey -- or so it often seems -- but an assortment of dukedoms and duchies, some 566 municipalities, that have drawn their power from the cherished concept of home rule.
docs.abstract: New Jersey Property Tax Commission proposes plan, backed by Gov Christine Whitman, for local governments to save money and raise efficiency by consolidating some education functions and municipal services; strength of state's long standing home-rule is seen as weakness by some experts; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a typical school day in Mill Valley, Calif., Paula Reynolds rises at 5:30 A.M., gets her two oldest children out the door by 7:45 and hops into the car to follow her youngest as he navigates his bike down the hill to school. Then she commutes to work to San Francisco, 45 minutes away. Five hectic hours later, she heads back home in time to greet her children -- Peter, 12; Julia, 9, and Charlie, 6 -- at the door at 3 P.M. ''My kids are at an age where they want to be with me more than anybody else,'' said Ms. Reynolds, 43, the co-owner of a firm that supplies temporary executives to corporations. So she works a 26-hour week, guaranteeing that she will have some afternoon hours with her children. ''I'll have plenty of time later to develop my career,'' she said.
docs.abstract: Article on growing number of full-time mothers who are finding part-time jobs so that they can spend more time at home; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WATCHING the premiums soar on his $100,000 life insurance policy as he advanced through his 70's, Leonard Oxenberg wondered why he was still making the payments. He no longer needed the coverage -- his son was grown, and his wife had a good job. And there were many other ways that Mr. Oxenberg, a retired advertising executive in Brookline, Mass., would have liked to be spending the $5,000, soon to be $6,000, that he was paying in annual premiums.

headline.main: Death Benefits, Now for The Living

docs.abstract: Article on growing number of financial companies and insurers that are buying back values of life insurance policies while insured is alive and healthy; says one company, Viaticus Inc, unit of CNA Financial Corp, expects to buy up to $300 million of policies this year, up from $75 million last year; holds Viaticare Financial Services expects to buy $100 million in policies, up from $18 million last year; some insurers welcome new approach while others question whether it will cost life insurance industry in long term; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE mom and apple pie, New Jersey's efforts at cost-cutting and greater efficiency have long produced reverent and pious pronouncements of devotion from state and local officials. Who, after all, would not want to save money? So when Governor Whitman announced a package of legislation and executive orders creating incentives for communities to lower local property taxes by sharing or consolidating services, her voice was yet another in the chorus trying to harmonize the state's governmental cacophony.
docs.abstract: Article recalls several earlier, unsuccessful, attempts to consolidate services in New Jersey communities in order to lower property taxes and be more efficient; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton, the House passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today that would be paid for by projected Federal budget surpluses. The vote put Republicans a step closer to a politically charged election-year showdown with the White House and Congressional Democrats over an issue that both sides believe will play to their advantage.

headline.main: SPLINTERED HOUSE APPROVES TAX CUT WORTH $80 BILLION

docs.abstract: House, voting largely along party lines, approves $80 billion Republican tax cut to be paid for by projected Federal budget surpluses, ignoring threat of veto from Pres Clinton, who says spending any surpluses before they materialize woud be reckless and endanger effort to address Social Security system's long-term financial problems; Senate Republicans could scale back House bill to try to win votes fro wavering Democrats; photo of Rep Bill Archer, author of bill, and Speaker New Gingrich (M)
docs.snippet: Brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton, the House passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today that would be paid for by projected Federal budget surpluses.    The vote put Republicans a step closer to a politically charged...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''A NATION of Clinton Enablers?'' a headline in The New York Post queried. ''We have all been enablers for Bill Clinton,'' declared Time magazine. Last week, an editorial in this newspaper spoke of Mr. Clinton's ''documentably dysfunctional personality'' and warned that ''we must not become a nation of enablers.'' In a recent speech, the television evangelist (and sometime Clinton counselor) Robert Schuller asserted that ''we all share part of the shame'' for stubbornly high public approval ratings that have enabled President Clinton so far to avoid confronting the problem of his sexual behavior. The American electorate has been called many things from the pulpit and in editorial pages. ''Enabling, to describe the behavior of a nation, though -- that's a new one,'' said Stanton Peele, an author and clinical psychologist who has studied what he regards as the two-decade-long march of the therapeutic ideal and its clinical concepts from personal behavior into ever-wider areas.

headline.main: The Nation; 'Enabling' Is Now a Political Disease

docs.abstract: Increasingly pseudo-clinical tone of discourse on Pres Clinton's woes includes depiction by commentators and clerics of American public as 'enablers' for continuing to support him; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just three months before a new era in the history of Medicare is to begin, members of Congress and health policy experts are expressing alarm that the Federal Medicare agency cannot meet statutory deadlines for many of the changes scheduled to take effect over the next two years. Overwhelmed with new responsibilities, Federal health officials say they will miss deadlines for some of the changes required by the 1997 budget law, which was adopted with bipartisan support. The changes are intended to save money and to modernize Medicare by opening the Government program to a wider range of private health plans.

headline.main: Congress Fears Medicare Will Miss Deadlines for Change

docs.abstract: Members of Congress and health policy experts fear that Health Care Financing Administration will not meet deadlines set in 1997 budget for making changes in Medicare intended to save money and to modernize system by opening it to wider range of private health plans; members of Federal commission studying how to preserve Medicare for baby boom generation also worry that some attractive policy options under consideration may prove unworkable because they cannot be carried out in a timely way; Republicans complain that Medicare officials are dragging their feet even though Clinton Administration proposed many of the changes (M)
